title: Alison Herlands and Michael Chessa: Law and Order and Love - The New York Times
text:
Continue reading the main story Photo Alison Beth Herlands and Michael John Chessa were married Feb. 11 at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Rabbi Rachel Timoner officiated. The bride, who is 33 and will be taking her husband’s name, works at Averity, a technical-recruitment firm in Manhattan, where she is responsible for business development and recruitment. Until March 2016, she was a litigation associate at Mintz & Gold, a law firm, also in Manhattan. She graduated cum laude from Tulane, from which she also received a law degree. She is the daughter of Susan H. Herlands and Scott A. Herlands of Scranton, Pa. The bride’s father is the owner of the Herlands & Levine Law Firm in Scranton. Her mother is the owner of My Mother’s Delicacies, a wholesale baking company, also in Scranton. The groom, 39, is a trial lawyer with Gersowitz Libo & Korek, a law firm in Manhattan. He graduated from the University of Colorado and received a law degree from Brooklyn Law School. He also received a master’s degree in English from Brooklyn College. He is the son of Judy L. Chessa and John V. Chessa of Peekskill, N.Y. His mother is the director of the Anxiety & Phobia Treatment Center at White Plains Hospital. His father is the owner of Total Concept Graphics, a printing brokerage company in Manhattan. 
Advertisement Continue reading the main story The couple met in January 2011 during a weeklong criminal-law orientation at the Brooklyn district attorney’s office, where they were assistant district attorneys. “The orientation was very intense and consisted of expert speakers on a variety of criminal subjects — arraignments, warrantless searches and victim services,” Mr. Chessa said. “What I remember most though, was this one woman and how her hand would shoot up as soon as the floor opened after each and every presenter. I remember thinking: ‘Who is this girl? Does she have a question for everything?’” That woman turned out to be Ms. Herlands, who had arrived in New York a year earlier from New Orleans, where she worked at Tulane’s Criminal Law Clinic as a student lawyer, representing defendants charged with felonies.
